step1.sentence: Leaders who communicate effectively build more trust and achieve better results.

step2.story: She had been told she needed to communicate more effectively, which was useful feedback that did not include any guidance about what more effectively meant. She asked for a specific example. The specific example was more useful than ten workshops would have been.

step3.story: The organization had invested in communication training every year for a decade. The evaluation data was consistent: short-term improvement, long-term reversion. The training director eventually proposed a different model — not training, but coaching: targeted, one-on-one support for specific communication challenges that real people were facing in real situations. The change in format required fewer people and more skill from the coaches. The behavior change that followed was more durable than anything the annual workshops had produced. Communicating effectively, it turned out, was best developed in the context of actual communication rather than instruction about it.
